tit.e: Government Organization of Early Modern Japan
tit.cmt: 対訳・定訳に、官制として官制→government-regulated organization or facility, etc.とありますが、government organizationで十分ではないかと思われますのでそのようにしました。また、近代をmodernとすると内容にある年代のみならず現代までも含まれてしまう可能性が高いので、early modernとしました。
tit.e: Government Organization of Early Modern Japan

sen.j: 近代日本の官制（きんだいにほんのかんせい）は、王政復古 (日本)によって明治維新が始まった慶応3年12月9日 (旧暦)（西暦1868年1月3日）から、内閣官制が制定された1889年（明治22年）12月24日に至るまでの中央政府における主な機関の変遷を概観する。
sen.e: Under the title "Government-regulated organization in modern Japan" changes of main agencies in the central government from January 3, 1868, when the Meiji restoration was started with Restoration of Imperial Rule, to December 24, 1889, when the official organization system under the Cabinet was established, are outlined.

Under the title "Government Organization of Early Modern Japan," this article outlines the changes of major agencies of the central government of Japan from rom January 3, 1868, when the Meiji restoration was started with Restoration of Imperial Rule, to December 24, 1889, when the official organization system under the Cabinet was established.

Under the title "Government Organization of Early Modern Japan," this article outlines the changes of major agencies of the central government of Japan from rom January 3, 1868, when the Meiji restoration was started with Restoration of Imperial Rule, to December 24, 1889, when the official organization system under the Cabinet was established.

sen.j: 近代以前の律令官制については日本の官制を、内閣制度については内閣 (日本)を参照。
sen.e: Refer to "Government-regulated organization in Japan" for government-regulated organization before the modern times, and refer to "Cabinet (Japan)" for the cabinet system.
For the government organization before modern times, refer to "Government Organization in Japan," and for the current cabinet system, refer to "Cabine of Japan," respectively.
For the government organization before modern times, refer to "Government Organization in Japan," and for the current cabinet system, refer to "Cabine of Japan," respectively.

sen.j: 三職
sen.e: Three Offices
Three Offices
Three Offices
from January 3, 1868 to June 11, 1868
From January 3, 1868 to June 11, 1868
sen.cmt: 文頭を大文字に変更しました。
sen.e: From January 3, 1868 to June 11, 1868

sen.j: 慶応3年12月9日（1868年1月3日）、総裁・議定・参与の三職を置き、摂政・関白・征夷大将軍・内覧・勅問・国事掛・議奏・武家伝奏・守護職・所司代を廃止した。
sen.e: On January 3, 1868, three offices (President, Gijo? and Councilor) were established, and Sessho Kampaku (regent and chief adviser to the Emperor), Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians"), Nairan (private inspection), Chokumon (questions by Emperor), Kokujigakari (officials in charge of affairs of State), Giso (a position conveying what the congress decides to Emperor), Buke Tenso (a position conveying messages between Emperor and buke (military authority)), Shugoshiki (military governor) and Shoshidai (representative of shoshi) were abolished.

On January 3, 1868, three offices of Sosai, Gijo and Sanyo (all of them, roughly concilors) were established, abolishing the positions of Sessho Kampaku (regent and chief adviser to the Emperor), Seii Taishogun (shogun, literally meaning, "great general who subdues the barbarians"), Nairan (private inspection), Chokumon (questions by Emperor), Kokujigakari (officials in charge of state affairs), Giso (a position conveying what the congress decides to Emperor), Buke Tenso (a position conveying messages between Emperor and the shogunate), Shugoshiki (military governor) and Shoshidai (the shogunate's military governor stationed in Kyoto).
sen.cmt: Gijo? --> GijiShoshidai (representative of shoshi) --> the shogunate's military governor stationed in Kyoto （新英和辞典から引きました）
sen.e: On January 3, 1868, three offices of Sosai, Gijo and Sanyo (all of them, roughly concilors) were established, abolishing the positions of Sessho Kampaku (regent and chief adviser to the Emperor), Seii Taishogun (shogun, literally meaning, "great general who subdues the barbarians"), Nairan (private inspection), Chokumon (questions by Emperor), Kokujigakari (officials in charge of state affairs), Giso (a position conveying what the congress decides to Emperor), Buke Tenso (a position conveying messages between Emperor and the shogunate), Shugoshiki (military governor) and Shoshidai (the shogunate's military governor stationed in Kyoto).

sen.j: 明治元年1月17日（1868年2月10日）、三職の職制を定めて分課した。
sen.e: On February 10, 1868, office organization of the three offices was established and sections were created.
On February 10, 1868, the structure of the three offices was regulated and organized.
On February 10, 1868, the structure of the three offices was regulated and organized.

sen.j: 明治元年2月3日（1868年2月25日）、7課を改めて8局とした（総裁局を新設）。
sen.e: On February 25, 1868, seven sections were reorganized into eight bureaux (General Bureau was created).
On February 25, 1868, seven sections were reorganized into eight bureaux (General Bureau was created).
On February 25, 1868, seven sections were reorganized into eight bureaux (General Bureau was created).

sen.j: 明治元年2月、徴士・貢士の制度を定めた。
sen.e: In February, 1868, the system of choshi (official) and koshi (representative of each domain) was established.
In February, 1868, the system of choshi (official) and koshi (representative of each domain) was established.
In February, 1868, the system of choshi (official) and koshi (representative of each domain) was established.

sen.j: 貢士を「下ノ議事所」の議事官とした。
sen.e: Koshi was made a member of the "Lower Meeting Place."
Koshi was appointed as member of the "Lower Meeting Place."
Koshi was appointed as member of the 'Lower Meeting Place.'

sen.j: 明治元年3月14日（1868年4月6日）、五箇条の御誓文により、政府の基本方針が示された。
sen.e: On April 6, 1868, the basic policies of the government were announced with "Charter Oath of Five Articles."
On April 6, 1868, the basic policies of the government were presented according to the Charter Oath of Five Articles.
On April 6, 1868, the basic policies of the government were presented according to the Charter Oath of Five Articles.

sen.j: 太政官制
sen.e: Daijokan System
Dajokansei (Dajokan system)
sen.cmt: 明治以降のシステムについては、だじょうかん、と読むのが通例だと思いますので変更しました。
sen.e: Dajokansei (Dajokan system)

sen.j: 政体書
sen.e: the Constitution of 1868
The Constitution of 1868
sen.cmt: 文頭大文字にしました。
sen.e: The Constitution of 1868
from June 11, 1868 to August 15, 1869
From June 11, 1868 to August 15, 1869
sen.cmt: 文頭大文字にしました。
sen.e: From June 11, 1868 to August 15, 1869

sen.j: 慶応4年閏4月21日（1868年6月11日）、太政官の権力を立法・行法・司法の三権に分け、それぞれ議政官・行政官・刑法官に担当させることなどを定めた政体書を出した。
sen.e: On April 11, 1868, the authority of Daijokan (Grand Council of State) was divided into legislation, execution and administration of justice and Giseikan, Gyoseikan (executive officer) and Keihokan respectively took charge of those authorities.

On April 11, 1868, the authority of Dajokan (Grand Council of State) was divided into legislative, executive and judicial branches, and each of them was led by Giseikan (an official to take charge of legislation), Gyoseikan (an official to take charge of administration) and Keihokan (an official to take charge of criminal justice), respectively.
sen.cmt: legislation, execution and administration o --> legislative, executive and judicial branches
sen.e: On April 11, 1868, the authority of Dajokan (Grand Council of State) was divided into legislative, executive and judicial branches, and each of them was led by Giseikan (an official to take charge of legislation), Gyoseikan (an official to take charge of administration) and Keihokan (an official to take charge of criminal justice), respectively.

sen.j: 明治元年7月17日（1868年9月3日）、明治天皇が東京に行幸し、江戸ヲ称シテ東京ト為スノ詔書を出した。
sen.e: On September 3, 1868, the Meiji Emperor visited Tokyo and issued an imperial edict for renaming Edo as Tokyo.
On September 3, 1868, the Meiji Emperor visited Tokyo and issued an imperial edict for renaming Edo as Tokyo.
On September 3, 1868, the Meiji Emperor visited Tokyo and issued an imperial edict for renaming Edo as Tokyo.

sen.j: 明治2年2月24日（1869年4月5日）、太政官を東京に移した。
sen.e: On April 5, 1869, Daijokan was relocated to Tokyo.
On April 5, 1869, Dajokan was relocated to Tokyo.
On April 5, 1869, Dajokan was relocated to Tokyo.

sen.j: 2官6省
sen.e: Two Officials and Six Ministries
Two Officials and Six Ministries
Two Officials and Six Ministries
from August 15, 1869 to September 13, 1871
From August 15, 1869 to September 13, 1871
sen.cmt: 文頭大文字にしました。
sen.e: From August 15, 1869 to September 13, 1871

sen.j: 明治2年6月17日（1869年7月25日）、版籍奉還が行われる。
sen.e: On July 25, 1869, lands and people were returned to Emperor ("hanseki hokan").
On July 25, 1869, lands and people were returned to Emperor ("hanseki hokan").
On July 25, 1869, lands and people were returned to Emperor ("hanseki hokan").

sen.j: 明治2年7月8日（1869年8月15日）、官位（官職と位階）を全面改正。
sen.e: On August 15, 1869, the whole system of job grades and court ranks was revised.
On August 15, 1869, the whole system of job grades and court ranks was revised.
On August 15, 1869, the whole system of job grades and court ranks was revised.

sen.j: 従来の百官・受領を全廃し、新たに2官6省を置く。
sen.e: The traditional Momono-tsukasa (many officials) and Zuryo (provincial governors) were totally abolished and two officials and six ministries were newly established.
sen.cmt: 定訳・読み方不明：百官
sen.e: The traditional Momono-tsukasa (many officials) and Zuryo (provincial governors) were totally abolished and two officials and six ministries were newly established.
The traditional Momono-tsukasa (many officials) and Zuryo (provincial governors) were totally abolished and two officials and six ministries were newly established.

sen.j: 従来、従四位以下にあった上下を廃止し、位階を正一位から少初位まで全18階とする（同年8月20日（1869年9月25日）、正九位を新設し、全20階とする。）。
sen.e: Jushii (Junior Fourth Rank) and lower ranks had been divided into two ("higher" and "lower") but such division was abolished, and court ranks were reorganized into eighteen stages from Shoichii (Senior First Rank) to Shosoi (Later Shokui (Senior Ninth Rank) was newly created and the number of court ranks increased to twenty on September 25, 1869).

Jushii (Junior Fourth Rank) and lower ranks had been divided into two ("higher" and "lower") but such division was abolished, and court ranks were reorganized into eighteen stages from Shoichii (Senior First Rank) to Shosoi (Later Shokui (Senior Ninth Rank) was newly created and the number of court ranks increased to twenty on September 25, 1869).

Jushii (Junior Fourth Rank) and lower ranks had been divided into two ("higher" and "lower") but such division was abolished, and court ranks were reorganized into eighteen stages from Shoichii (Senior First Rank) to Shosoi (Later Shokui (Senior Ninth Rank) was newly created and the number of court ranks increased to twenty on September 25, 1869).

sen.j: 三院制
sen.e: Tricameral System
Tricameral System
Tricameral System
from September 13, 1871 to April 14, 1875
From September 13, 1871 to April 14, 1875
sen.cmt: 文頭大文字にしました。
sen.e: From September 13, 1871 to April 14, 1875

sen.j: 明治4年7月14日（1871年8月29日）、廃藩置県が行われる。
sen.e: On August 29, 1871, feudal domains were abolished and prefectures were established ("haihan chiken").
On August 29, 1871, feudal domains were abolished and prefectures were established ("haihan chiken").
On August 29, 1871, feudal domains were abolished and prefectures were established ("haihan chiken").

sen.j: 明治4年7月29日（1871年9月13日）、官制を改正する。
sen.e: On September 13, 1871, government-regulated organizations were revised.
On September 13, 1871, the government organization was revised.
On September 13, 1871, the government organization was revised.

sen.j: 明治4年8月10日（1871年9月24日）、官制を改正する。
sen.e: On September 24, 1871, government-regulated organizations were revised.
On September 24, 1871, government organization was revised.
On September 24, 1871, government organization was revised.

sen.j: 従来の官位相当制を廃止し、新たに全15等の官等を設けた。
sen.e: The traditional Kanisoto Sei (the ranks of the bureaucracy system of the ritsuryo system) was abolished and new official ranks (fifteen in total) were created.
The traditional Kanisoto Sei (the ranks of the bureaucracy system of the ritsuryo system) was abolished and new official ranks (fifteen in total) were created.
The traditional Kanisoto Sei (the ranks of the bureaucracy system of the ritsuryo system) was abolished and new official ranks (fifteen in total) were created.

sen.j: 明治8年の官制
sen.e: Government-regulated organizations in 1875
The government organization introduced in 1975
The government organization introduced in 1975
from April 14, 1875 to December 22, 1885
From April 14, 1875 to December 22, 1885
sen.cmt: 文頭大文字にしました。
sen.e: From April 14, 1875 to December 22, 1885

sen.j: 1875年（明治8年）2月11日、大阪会議が行われる。
sen.e: On February 11, 1875, Osaka conference was held.
On February 11, 1875, Osaka conference was held.
On February 11, 1875, Osaka conference was held.

sen.j: 1875年（明治8年）4月14日、立憲政体の詔書（漸次立憲政体樹立の詔）が出される。
sen.e: On April 14, 1875, Shosho((imperial edict) for gradually establishing the constitutional system of government was issued.
On April 14, 1875, the imperial edict to establish a constitutional government (gradually establishing the constitutional government) was issued.
On April 14, 1875, the imperial edict to establish a constitutional government (gradually establishing the constitutional government) was issued.

from December 22, 1885 to December 24, 1889

sen.e: From December 22, 1885 to December 24, 1889

sen.j: 1885年（明治18年）12月22日、明治18年太政官達第69号および内閣職権を定めて太政官制を廃止し、内閣制を創設する。
sen.e: On December 22, 1885, with the No.69 Dajokan tasshi (proclamation by the Grand Council of State) of 1885 and by establishing the authorities of the Cabinet, the system of Daijokan was abolished and the Cabinet system was created.

On December 22, 1885, with the No.69 Dajokan tasshi (proclamation by the Grand Council of State) of 1885 and by establishing the authorities of the Cabinet, the system of Daijokan was abolished and the Cabinet system was created.

On December 22, 1885, with the No.69 Dajokan tasshi (proclamation by the Grand Council of State) of 1885 and by establishing the authorities of the Cabinet, the system of Daijokan was abolished and the Cabinet system was created.

from December 24, 1889 to May 3, 1947

sen.j: 1889年（明治22年）12月24日、内閣官制（明治22年勅令第135号）を定める。
sen.e: On December 24, 1889, the official organization system under the Cabinet (No.135 Imperial Edict of 1889) was established.
On December 24, 1889, the official organization system under the Cabinet (No.135 Imperial Edict of 1889) was established.
